CONJUGATES: plateaus (pl., n.) | plateaux (less common pl., n.) | plateaus (3rd pers. sing., v.) | plateauing (pres. part.) | plateaued (past tense/p.p.)
ETYMOLOGY: From French plateau, diminutive of plat ('flat dish'), derived from Old French platel. Adopted into English first to describe a decorative centerpiece or tray, and later applied to geography (mid-18th century).

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A large area of relatively level high ground; a tableland.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The explorers reached a high plateau after several days of difficult climbing.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 经过几天艰难的攀登，探险家们到达了一处高地。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A period or state of little or no change following a period of activity or growth; a stable level.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 稳定期；停滞期（指发展或增长停止在某一水平上）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: After months of intense study, my ability to recall vocabulary seems to have reached a plateau.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 经过数月的紧张学习，我的词汇量记忆能力似乎进入了一个瓶颈期/稳定期。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To reach a stable level or period of no change after a period of increase or decrease.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 达到平稳状态；停止增长或下降；稳定下来。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Economists predict that inflation will plateau in the third quarter.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 经济学家预测通货膨胀将在第三季度趋于平稳。

REGISTER: General usage, particularly common in professional and academic contexts (economics, learning, geography).
